metadata.methodology: Behavioral paleography -- ligatures identified by continuous pen movement and functional unity
metadata.notes: Ligatures are character sequences written as connected units. In the ZFD shorthand system, many EVA multi-character sequences are actually single functional units.

ligatures.description: The q-descender flows directly into the o-circle without pen lift. The two characters form a single pen movement.
ligatures.evidence: q appears without following o in fewer than 1.5% of cases. The pen movement is continuous in all examined folios.

ligatures.function: Action/directional operator or consonant cluster element
ligatures.description: The crescent (c) connects directly to the h-stroke. Written as a single pen movement. The c-component is identical in shape to standalone 'e'.
ligatures.evidence: The c and h are never separated by a word boundary. Continuous pen movement confirmed across all examined folios.
ligatures.critical_note: The distinction between standalone 'e' and the 'c' of 'ch' is CONTEXTUAL, not visual. If followed by 'h'-stroke, it is 'ch'. Otherwise, it is 'e'.

ligatures.description: S-curve flows into crescent flows into h-stroke. Three visual components, one continuous pen movement.

The 'a' circle-tail flows into a series of connected minims (ii) ending with a final stroke (n). The entire sequence shows continuous pen movement. The 'ii' portion is a connected minim sequence, not two separate strokes.
ligatures.evidence: In all examined folios, the aiin sequence shows no clear pen lifts between components. The minim sequence is rhythmically connected.
ligatures.critical_note: This is the strongest evidence for a LIGATURE-BASED shorthand system. If aiin were four separate letters, we would expect to see pen lifts. We do not.

ligatures.description: Like 'aiin' but with three minims instead of two. Same continuous pen movement.
ligatures.evidence: Same continuous movement as aiin, with additional minim.

ligatures.function: Operator d- + suffix aiin: dose/give + substance
ligatures.description: The d-loop-ascender is followed (with possible pen lift) by the aiin ligature unit. Often written as a complete word-unit.
ligatures.evidence: Very common word. The d may or may not connect directly to the aiin unit.

ligatures.description: The o-circle flows directly into the r-hook. Common stem element.
ligatures.evidence: Continuous pen movement observed in most cases.

ligatures.description: The o-circle connects to the l-stroke. Oil/liquid semantic marker.
Crescent e flows into descender y.
Crescent e connects to d-loop, then flows into descender y.
ligatures.evidence: Consistent suffix pattern in pharmaceutical vocabulary.

ligatures.description: Like aiin but with single minim.
Double crescent (ee) followed by descender y. The double-e may represent a single elongated crescent.
ligatures.critical_note: The 'ee' sequence may be a single glyph (elongated crescent) rather than two separate 'e' characters.

ligatures.description: Crescent connects to t-gallows with h-stroke continuation. Written as a connected unit.
ligatures.evidence: The crescent-gallows-h compound shows continuous pen movement through the gallows.

ligatures.description: Crescent connects to k-gallows with h-stroke continuation.
Crescent connects to p-gallows with h-stroke continuation.
Crescent connects to f-gallows with h-stroke continuation.
